section.title: Overview
section.p: Mutt-ng is a small but very powerful text-based MIME mail client. Mutt-ng is highly configurable, and is well suited to the mail power user with advanced features like key bindings, keyboard macros, mail threading, regular expression searches and a powerful pattern matching language for selecting groups of messages to perform various of types of actions with.

The project started off with the mutt code base and got extended with more usefull features written on our own as well as patches which were already available for mutt. However, by the time we more and more ran into the problem that we found the code (mostly) too complex, not well enough documented and hardly maintainable any longer when it came to tracking down underlying problems of bug reports we received. As the consequence, we started to redesign and rewrite everything from scratch.
For the rewrite, the main design objectives are:

ul.li: Logic separation of funtionality. It turned out that there were too few abstraction layers in general but special treatment in just too many places. Also it seemed that the main design wasn't questioned at all but just got extended by more conditional parts in-place instead of migrating to better abstraction models. For the rewrite, we thus use the following layer model described later in detail: a core part containing very low level but not mail-related functionality, a libmuttng library with all mail-related logic and a muttng part with user interfaces just using the two lower layers as needed. Within each, we separate features and functionality as much as possible to move to a more modular system.

Documentation. For developers there virtually wasn't any documentation about the design decissions made, the general interaction between different parts nor which parts there were. The user-manual was good by means of quantity but not quality. For the rewrite, we provide much better documentation for users and for developers in as many languages as we find translators for. The manual will be completely rewritten, that is, better structured, better examples and more accessible for users new to mutt-ng. For developers there's better documentation, too. Functions are not only documented, within the different layers they're also grouped by their purpose including reasoning for the grouping structure. The developer's guide contains plenty documentation and ready-to-use examples which are included from compileable source code (no copy'n'paste is required, examples are verified automatically to compile and work.)

Quality ensurance. As the libmuttng as well as the muttng layer is written in C++, there're so-called unit tests which are run automatically to see if a certain part works. This greatly improves maintainability of the code base not only during the rewrite process but also when a redesign is required in the future (as this will certainly be the case, we already prepare for it.)

section.title: Mutt-ng Home Page
section.p: The official hompepage of mutt-ng is: http://www.muttng.org/
While the rewrite is maintained in a branch, the homepage for it is: http://www.muttng.org/rewrite/.

section.title: Mailing Lists
section.p: The following mailing lists are available:

ul.li: mutt-ng-users@lists.berlios.de: This is where the mutt-ng user support happens.
mutt-ng-devel@lists.berlios.de: The development mailing list for mutt-ng

section.title: Software Distribution Sites
section.p: So far, there are no official releases of Mutt-ng, but you can download daily snapshots from http://mutt-ng.berlios.de/snapshots/ for the ``old'' version.

section.title: IRC
section.p: Visit channel #muttng on irc.freenode.net (see http://www.freenode.net/) to chat with other people interested in Mutt-ng.

section.title: Weblog
section.p: If you want to read fresh news about the latest development in Mutt-ng, and get informed about stuff like interesting, Mutt-ng-related articles and packages for your favorite distribution, you can read and/or subscribe to our development weblog at http://mutt-ng.supersized.org/.
